text: welcome to how to cook that I'm Ann
Reardon and today let's get creative
I've got a couple of trays for chalks or
pastels here and I thought how cool
would it be if we could put chocolates
in these in all different flavors it
would be a great gift for an art lover I
wasn't quite sure how to make a mold for
them so I thought what I'd do is start
with two pieces of wood and then cut
them to little lengths so that they'll
fit into the slots for the chalks I've
got two different widths of wood here of
course because the chalk boxes that I've
got were two different sizes I'm going
to take four of those pieces of wood and
glue them down in a row there like that
and then take some slightly taller wood
and glue it into a rectangle and put it
around the edge I'm just using a hot
glue gun to put this together so that I
can pull it apart later then fill that
with reusable food grade molding gel
this stuff is great too this is not a
product placement I just really like it
if you don't have molding gel I'll show
you another option later in the video
that you can do now for the flavors I'm
gonna go with lime orange passion fruit
licorice mint and strawberry so for each
of these we need to make a filling hole
the strawberries wash them and then put
them into a fine sieve then you just
want to squash them using the back of
your spoon and keep pressing them
against the sieve and tell you a left
with just a slurry of the seeds to the
strawberry juice add some white
chocolate and I'll put all the recipe
quantities for these on the
howtocookthat.net website for you and
there's a link to that below then
microwave that for 40 seconds there
abouts and give it a stir and this also
makes a yummy strawberry ice cream
topping - even if you're not making
chocolates you can give this a try
once all the chocolate is mixed in you
just want to set that aside to cool next
to make our orange filling we need some
fresh orange juice and some orange rind
make sure you just get the orange part
and not the bitter white fit add in some
white chocolate
and then microwave that and stir it
until it's all combined
now you can strain this to remove the
rind or you can leave it in for a
stronger flavor I quite like to leave it
in now on to the fresh passionfruit
scoop out all of that pulp and then
using a spoon push through as much of
the juice and pulp as you can you could
leave the seeds in your ganache if you
wanted to but my chocolates are quite
skinny so I'm going to take them out
add in the white chocolate microwave
that for about 40 seconds or until the
chocolate is melted and of course stir
it until it's smooth the passionfruit is
one of my favorite ganache flavors
because it's just such a robust flavor
and it just tastes so good leave that
one to set as well for the liquorice one
I'm going to have some crunchy chips of
humbugs in the chocolate you could make
a ganache but I wanted a bit of
variation in the texture of our
chocolates
so once you've smashed those up just pop
them into a bowl and cover it with some
plastic wrap so they don't get sticky
make the lime filling in the same way as
we did for the orange one just by mixing
together your lime juice and your white
chocolate make sure you do taste each of
these to me the lime one is a little bit
too sweet so I'm going to add the
tiniest bit of salt to balance it out I
wanted to use fresh mint for the next
one
but this is all that we have left in the
garden because the caterpillars have
eaten the rest so instead I'm going to
use a little bit of peppermint essence
not too much because this is very strong
and then add some cream and microwave
that one too now back to the molds use a
knife to lift it off the base and then
use your muscles to pull the edges off
the mold then you want to gently loosen
around all those molded bits and push it
out from the back and then just pull it
until it comes out and you have a lovely
perfect mold there temper some dark
chocolate and add to it some oil-based
black food coloring if you use
water-based coloring or gel coloring
it'll seize your chocolate
so make sure you get oil-based coloring
then stir that in and with the black I
find it does get black up over time so I
know this still looks a bit browning now
but you wait a couple of hours and it
will look really black tip that into
your mold and fill it right up now you
can use a spoon or a knife or whatever
you've got to spread that out make sure
they're all full pop some baking paper
underneath and then flip the mold over
and give it a good shake what this does
is it tips out the chocolate that's in
the middle but it leaves the shell of
chocolate around the edges use a spatula
and then just scrape off the excess off
the top once that's it you can add your
filling for the black one of course I'm
using the licorice flavored humbug chips
top that off with more chocolate and
then tap it on the counter to get rid of
any air bubbles wipe off the excess
chocolate and leave them to set for all
the other colors use tempered white
chocolate mixed with the oil based food
colorings tip it into the mold
shake it out just like we did for the
black one and then let it set and then
add your fillings I had to make a blue
one of course because every art set has
blue in it but I didn't make a ganache
for blue so I think I'm going to use
some chopped hazelnuts in this one for
the ganache piping it in is the easiest
way to get it in the right spot you
don't want it to touch the top of the
edges or it won't seal when you add the
chocolate on top what's there set push
from the bottom of the mold and gently
take them out look at that if you do
happen to have any tiny little bit
sticking out on the bottom edge just run
a blade down to neaten it up and they
look like they belong in an art set I'll
put them in in a sec but firstly I want
to show you what you can do if you don't
have mold and gel or oil based food
coloring take the tray out of the box
and fill it with milk chocolate or white
or dark whichever you prefer make sure
you temper it though and spread it into
all the holes then scrape off the excess
into the bowl drop it a few times to get
rid of any air bubbles and then flip it
over like we did with the other mole
and tip out the chocolate from the
middle scrape off the top again and then
once it is set fill each section with a
different flavor of filling that we made
cover that up with more chocolate and
scrape off the excess to level it once
it's set flip it over and push it out
and you end up with this cool-looking
chocolate bar that will fit perfectly
into your box and each segment of course
has a different flavored filling inside
back to our colored ones place those in
the box
they turned out looking great and the
